intro: Gilia abramsii subsp. integrifolia, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as rocky soils and desert scrublands. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often entire or slightly toothed. This subspecies is known for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for various wildlife species.
